awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Standard Grant: Artificial Intelligence and Predictive Policing: An Ethical Analysis
awd_abstract_narration:
This project is a study of the use of artificial intelligence to assist police on patrol by using massive troves of historical crime data to train machine learning algorithms to anticipate the timing and location of criminal activity. Predictive policing has come under intense criticisms from civil rights groups, academics, and communities that have been subject to predictive policing. These criticisms include its recapitulation of racially biased patterns of policing, its further burdening of marginalized communities, and its infringement on the liberties of targeted communities. The researchers propose to examine these claims and to develop best practices for the development and deployment of algorithmic policing programs. The results of this project promise to benefit police departments, communities patrolled based on algorithmic crime predictions, and public understanding of the societal and ethical implications of predictive policing. 

The aims of this grant are to examine and develop viable ethical frameworks for the assessment of predictive policing practices. In doing so, the researchers will propose and evaluate novel considerations that might bear on the ethics of predictive policing. They will also develop empirically grounded recommendations for the ethically sensitive and effective development and use of predictive policing. The results of this project promise to advance understanding and illuminate fertile new areas of research in moral philosophy, technology ethics, sociology, and criminology. They also will have clear relevance for other algorithmic technologies with similar implications for justice including algorithms that predict criminal sentences, make healthcare diagnoses, and serve as gatekeepers to government benefits (all of which are currently in use).

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project has pioneered academic, public, and industry discussions of predictive policing and yielded substantial academic publications. These academic publications have garnered 60 citations and climbing, enriching the academic discourse and providing novel insights into the ethical and social dimensions of predictive policing. These academic products are among the most-cited recent products in their academic areas.

The project has facilitated an estimated 120 undergraduate and graduate student hours at UF and approximately 80 undergraduate student research hours at Cal Poly, and has contributed to the academic progression of a postdoctoral fellow who subsequently secured a tenure-track position at a major research university. The project team, with a proven record of scholarly contributions and public engagement, has been actively disseminating knowledge through public-facing lectures, writing for the general public, 21 academic presentations, two professional trainings in data ethics for community college instructors, serving as chair of a local citizen-led police advisory council, and organizing panel events at major academic gatherings in philosophy.

The project’s commitment to actionable insights is highlighted by the completion of a major landscaping report in the project’s first year and a closing report consisting of 70+ ethically-informed and empirically-grounded recommendations, coupled with a closing workshop involving stakeholders for multiple academic disciplines, industry, law enforcement, and community advocacy.

Through various presentations and lectures, the project team has effectively broadened participation and increased public scientific literacy on the ethical and social considerations of algorithmic technology in the law enforcement and criminal justice domains. 

The project’s outcomes are poised to offer invaluable insights to various stakeholders, including police departments, communities subjected to algorithmically-directed patrols, and the public. The project’s recommendations have been adopted by a major policing technology firm, which is currently working with the principal investigators to implement changes in a pilot, epitomizing the close collaboration between academics and industry practitioners that are needed to drive the responsible creation and adoption of these sensitive technologies.
